title: Weyl law
summary: In mathematics, especially spectral theory, Weyl's law describes the asymptotic behavior of eigenvalues of the Laplace–Beltrami operator. This description was discovered in 1911 (in the d = 2 , 3 {\displaystyle d=2,3} case) by Hermann Weyl for eigenvalues for the Laplace–Beltrami operator acting on functions that vanish at the boundary of a bounded domain Ω ⊂ R d {\displaystyle \Omega \subset \mathbb {R} ^{d}} . In particular, he proved that the number, N ( λ ) {\displaystyle N(\lambda )} , of Dirichlet eigenvalues (counting their multiplicities) less than or equal to λ {\displaystyle \lambda } satisfies
